brace hundreds of Negroes who
could benefit from it.


During the pa st years, two ma
tional Urban League programs
were widely utilized In other
cities. namely, the voters regis
tration drive and the vocational
skills training program.


Here in Phoenix little was
heard of these programs or any
others. Urban League activities
should be made known in order to
win support financially as we'll
is participation.


There are more of the "have
nots'' in Phoenix who should
be aware of the services offered
by the Urban League. 1t is time
for the Phoenix Urban League to
have some new directions.

Views, pRevIEws
AMO REVIEWS


Edward Banks

Tunius Bowman, the new exc
cutive director of the Phoenix
Urban League, has assumed his
duties. He has great oppor-
tunity to review the policies ofthe
league and set up a more in
elusive program.


1t is hoped that MIR. Bowman
will strive to make the Phoenix
Urban League, which is United
Fund agency, more meaningful
among more than a handful of
Negroes.


The Urban League should not
become a center of activities
for group who wish to use it
mrely as a social outlet. The
league should aim to present the
national program and institute
local programs which will en-

NEW YORK = Negroes scored
the most spectacular political ad-
vance since Reconstruction in the
national elections, Tuesday, No
vember 8. Negro office seekers,
for the first time, won seats
in four state legislatures and
gained additional spots in other
state houses where they had pre-
viously served, while winning to
several state judgeships, county
and city posts.


The top Negro officeholder,
Ma ssachusetts Attorney General
Edward w. Brooke (Republican),
was reelected by 81 margin.


Detroit voters sent the sixth
Negro congressman to Wash
ington and the second from that
city when they elected John !.
Conyers Democrat) to the U.s..
House of Repre- sentatives.


MIR. Conyers will join the other
five whom voters reelected, in
Guiding Charles c. Diggs, Jr.,
of Detroit; Adam Clayton Powell
of New York City; William L.
Dawson of Chicago; Robert c.
Nix of Philadelphia; and Augustus
F. Hawkins of Los Angeles. All
are Democrats.


States sending Negroes to their
legislatures for the first time
included Iowa, 2; Oklahoma, 8;
Delaware, Kansas and Tennessee
one each.


New York and New Jersey
voters picked additional Negroes
to repre- sent them. In New York
Arthur Hardwicke, Jr., of Buff
falo; Kenneth N. Browne of
Queens; and William Thompson
of Brooklyn we're the three Sc

lected. A total of nine Negroes
were among those elected to the
New York State Legislature. This
included the reelection of Mrs.
Constance Baker Motley to the
State Senate.


Georgia voters not only sent
Leroy Johnson back to the State
Senate but elected another
Negro : Horace Ward = to that
body also. Other states reflect
ing Negro incumbents included
Wa shington, Ohio, Arizona and
Nebra ska.


Negroes also picked up more
seats in the Legislatures of In
diana, California and Ma ssa-
chusetts.


First we're scored when a
Negro was picked for a district
Judge in Colorado and when two
Negroes gained seats on the New
York State Supreme Court bench.
The New Workers we're Edward
R. Dudley, former Manhattan
Borough President, and Darwin
w. Telesford.


In Illinois, Theodore A. Jones



was elected University of
Illinois trustee by more than
100000 votes.


Four Negroes won offices in
Macon County (Birmingham) Ala
bama. Elected we're Rev. V. A.
Edwards, Board of Revenue;
Charles c. Condition, School
Board; William c. Allen and
William ]. Childs, Justices of
the Peace.


Savannah, Ca, gained it first
Negro city councilman in recent
history.

The first Negro to serve as the attorney
general of MasSa chusettS, EdsOaYd Brooke,
NON his second term ON the Republican ticket.
He had refused to support Barry G0ld,OuteY
and he re ceived an oUe1z0lae inning victoyy
from many Democrats aO)ao split their UOtes.


HIS U5ctoYy can not be labeled as racial
be cause Negroes COMPRISE only small bOY-
ton Of the population in Massa cKusetts.
BroOke's Uicto1y can be attributed to his
ability and personality. He has been a ded-
icated Republican Party yorker for many
years and said he could not support the
baaty's presidential nominee be cause he
felt their PHILOSOPHERS weYe too different.


In a nationwide telec0St last Sunday, Mr.:
Brooke, the highest elected official Of his
race, Teaft597ned his belief in the Rebubh-
can Party, but felt that party leaders should
begin to rebuild the party SO that minority
groups aOill be reached.


EduuYd ByoOke's de- isive victory clearly
Shows that the color Of skin is becoming less
a factor in politics as in other areas.

have been plagued by drippy
spouts in the bathroom and kit
chen.


Another source of irritation is
the malfunction In the water
closet fthe lavatory. Sometimes
the ball refuses to perform as
1t should and the sound of water
continues until the repairs are
made.


Have you ever been forced to
telephone the plumber after tin
kering for hours on the faucet
or water closet7 Did he arrive
and ca silly make the repair then
present you staggering blow
the bill for eight or ten dollars7


When he left your domicile have
you wished that you had a wee
part of his trade secrets7 Have
you thought of enrolling in a
plumbing urse7 Have you hoped
that some inventor would make
leakless faucet or a waterless
lavatory7


No earth shaking inventions
have been patented yet which
would keep our plumbing woes
away. However, the u. S. De-
partment ofAgriculture ha S come
to the aid of us who are subject
to leaky faucets or other plumbing
troubles.


Prepared by the agricultural
engineering research division of
the Agricultural Research Ser
vice, a bulletin, Farmers Bull
letin No. 22O2, "Simple Plumbing
Repairs for the Home and Farm
stead" was recently issued.


For a dime, ten cents or ten
pennies. you can" save money and
avoid delays by making minor
plumbing repairs" The table of
contents reveals intere sting
topics including repairing water
faucets, pipes, and closets: frost
proofing MIGRANTS: thawing frozen
water pipes: and clearing clogged
fixture and floor drains.


Two pages in the sixteen page
bulletin are devoted to listing
tools and parts required for re-
pair work and what to do in
ca ses of emergency.


After reading the booklet and
attempting to stop water closet
| decided it is ca sier though
costlier to call your friend, the
plumber.


The basic tools required to
have for simple home repairs
include all types and sizes of
wrenches, screwdrivers to fit
all pipes, fixtures and fittings,
a ball peen hammer. rubber
force cup plunger. cold chisel,
a center punch, cleanout auger,
friction tape and pair of ad-
Unstable pliers.


A dozen more additional tools
are listed for more extensive re-
pair work. Spare parts which
also may be needed are listed in
another column.


The most intriguing portion of
the booklet Is the first paragraph
written under the subtitle
"Emergencies." 1t instructs
readers to keep the name,
adore IS, and phone number of
plumber offering "a hour service
posted in a ca sy to reach place.


Perhaps the vacant space on
the last page is provided for
names and other pertinent in
formation needed by those per-
sons who start their simple re-
pair jobs.


One would need the names and
phone numbers of the water COM
pany, the electric company. the
nearest plumber (who will charge
the lea st amount), and the plum
ha- ,,,ho will Copoo froCo Y.dlocc

EDWARD BANKS, PUBL 'sHER-Eo'ToR


ELOlSE BANKS, ASSISTANT EDITOR
